title: Exception: PDB stream should not be given when embedding PDB into the PE stream.
body:

```
<Project Sdk="Microsoft.NET.Sdk.Web">

  <PropertyGroup>
    <TargetFramework>net47</TargetFramework>

  <PropertyGroup>
    <DebugType>embedded</DebugType>

title: Password isn't rendered in the view
body:
In my application's Change Password view, I request the user to enter the current and the new password. If something isn't correct, an error message is displayed for the appropriate input field. So if the current password is correct but the new password isn't allowed or something, the following happens:

* The current password has no error, but after submitting the form and returning back to it, it's empty
* The new password has an error message and is now empty, too

The issue is that the validation only represents what the user has provided, but doesn't consider what MVC has changed. It doesn't output passwords into their corresponding text fields at all, thereby producing more errors than indicated.

I've found some clues that this is supposed to be a "security measure" to prevent me from accidently leaking plain passwords to the UI where they could be recovered. This cannot possibly happen to me because I never store plain passwords in the system. And I also take great care to not make such mistakes.

So, after I have acknowledged this warning, can you please put me back into control and let me disable that behaviour so that any form input behaves just like I'd expect it to do?

title: Add more fine grained logging to RazorViewCompiler
Memory Leak in ASP.NET 2.0.5
body:
I'm developing an web app using asp.net core. When I run the app in VS 2017 (15.5.5) with Diagnostic tools enabled, memory is constantly increasing at-least 10 to 20MB per click. I thought the app has a memory leak and troubleshooting the app for many hours and I've landed on this link https://blog.markvincze.com/troubleshooting-high-memory-usage-with-asp-net-core-on-kubernetes/

I have created a new project from ASP.NET Core - Web Application Template which has few razor pages and returns HTML. When I refresh the page continuously (like a smoke test) the memory gradually increases from 200MB to 500MB and even more...

have a look on [this](https://www.screencast.com/t/Fpe348hEU)

As suggested in Mark Vincze blog, I've added following config in .csproj

`<PropertyGroup> 
    <ServerGarbageCollection>false</ServerGarbageCollection>
</PropertyGroup>`

Unfortunately it doesn't help. Memory still increases gradually. 

All ASP.NET Packages are up-to-date https://www.screencast.com/t/iaQVx9bH5Y1
OS: Windows 10 (1709)
IDE: Visual Studio 2017 (15.5.5) 
ASP.NET 2.0.5

Steps to reproduce:
1) Create a project in Visual Studio (ASP.NET Core - Web Application)
2) Run the project with Diagnostic tools enabled
3) Refresh the page continuously and watch the diagnostic tool
4) Memory will increase gradually.

title: Unexpected default path of view component views
body:
For example, create a view component named "Menu" and invoke it from a view used in a controller named "Home". In the view component's `Invoke()` method, call `View("Menu.cshtml")`. ## Expected Finds Menu.cshtml in the default location for this component and controller pair aka the first location searched when using the view name `"Menu"`: `Views/Home/Components/Menu/Menu.cshtml` ## Actual Finds Menu.cshtml in the *controller*'s default view folder: `Views/Home/Menu.cshtml` ## Not found case Doing the same thing without a matching `Menu.cshtml` file confirms the name is treated as a relative path, not a name to search for. ``` InvalidOperationException: The view 'Components/Menu/Menu.cshtml' was not found. The following locations were searched: /Views/Home/Menu.cshtml ``` ### Additional logging issue Though the locations searched are correct, the `Message` is not. `Components/Menu/Menu.cshtml` and `Views/Home/Components/Menu/Menu.cshtml` are not checked. MVC is logging with an edited "view name" that's never used because Menu.cshtml is a relative path. ## Documentation The view component documentation (https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/aspnet/core/mvc/views/view-components) does not mention passing a relative path to `View(...)` within a view component. ## Suggestions 1. Allow users to opt into using `~/Views/{Controller}/Components/{Component}/` as the default path for relative paths passed to `View(...)` within a view component. Because view components have been around for a release or so, can't change the default path (i.e. the `ViewContext.ExecutingFilePath` on entering `Invoke()`) without a breaking change. Likely need another `RazorViewEngineOptions` or `MvcViewOptions` property. This is based on an assumption that the root cause is `ExecutingFilePath` doesn't change from the view invoking the component i.e. where `Component.Invoke[Async](...)` was called. 2. Correct the failed search `Exception.Message` to use the original view name or path. 3. Document the interpretation of relative paths with and without the new property set. ## First scenario details ``` c# public class HomeController : Controller { public IActionResult Index() { return View(); } } [ViewComponent(Name = "Menu")] public class MenuComponent : ViewComponent { public IViewComponentResult Invoke() { return View("Menu.cshtml"); } } ``` ### Views/Home/Index.cshtml ``` html
@await Component.InvokeAsync("Menu")
``` ### Views/Home/Components/Menu/Menu.cshtml Exists but is not invoked ### Views/Home/Menu.cshtml ``` html

Menu.cshtml in controller (@Path).

```

title: Precompiled views are not being used even when they are available
Completely Disabling Antiforgery
body:
Hi,

   I'm trying to completely disable antiforgery, but it seems this is not possible. The documentation seems to suggest that using AddMvcCore as the only service will disable anti forgery. Whilst this seems true in that the tokens are not validated, the .aspnet.antiforgery token still gets set as a cookie in any requests omitting it. 

Trying to manually remove any services which are anti forgery related will throw an exception when attempting to view a view, such as:

InvalidOperationException: Unable to resolve service for type 'Microsoft.AspNetCore.Antiforgery.IAntiforgery' while attempting to activate 'Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.ViewFeatures.DefaultHtmlGenerator'.

Is there any way to completely get rid of the cookies issued? I know i can rename them, but this isn't really the point.

Thanks!

title: Prevent NullReferenceException when calling View() with null model
body:
Addresses #7378

In addition to the null checking, I added a condition to make sure existing unit tests does not fail, namely:
- DropDownListFor_WithUnrelatedExpression_GeneratesExpectedValue
- ListBoxFor_WithUnreleatedExpression_GeneratesExpectedValue
(I also fixed this unit test name typo: releated => related)

I am not sure if this is the correct/elegant way to address this issue, but I have successfully confirmed that it works after "patching" the official binary (Microsoft.AspNetCore.Mvc.ViewFeatures.dll, 2.1.0-preview2-30106) with this modified version.
(This is my first PR. I know I should have discussed it before sending this PR. To satisfy my curiosity, I tried to fix it for exercise, but later decided to try to send this PR.)

What I see quite often in almost if it's in all the Razor Pages, that we need to specify the model using the `@model`
```html
@page
@model ProductModel

for Product.cshtml, and
```html
@page
@model CustomerModel
```
for Customer.cshtml

Can we introduce a new option that allow us to set the model by convention `{PageName}Model` unless we need to use a different name

title: Remove RazorProject ViewEngine constructor
body: It's currently marked as obsolete. In the next major release we should remove it.

title: Remove service registration of Legacy Razor compilation infrastructure
body: Today we have service registrations for non-breaking reasons for the `RazorProject`, `MvcRazorTemplateEngine` and `RazorEngine` types. Now that we've moved to `RazorProjectEngine` we can remove all of these registrations in the next major release.

title: Move to RazorProjectEngine.
body:
- Updated our consumption of `RazorEngine` and `RazorTemplateEngine` to use `RazorProjectEngine` and its features.
- Updated service registrations to maintain existing services but to also register new ones.
- When moving `RazorViewEngine` to use `RazorProjectFileSystem` I had to add an unused constructor item in order to disambiguate the constructors.
- Updated tests to use `RazorProjectEngine` and `RazorProjectFileSystem`.

#7377 

/cc @mkArtakMSFT

title: Rename PartialTagHelper asp-for to for
body:
The `PartialTagHelper` is a brand new element and therefore we shouldn't be prefixing the for property on the `TagHelper`

/cc @pranavkm

title: Question: Why model accessor is swallowing NullReferenceException?
body:
### Minimal repro steps
1. Enable Visual Studio 2017 Exception Settings: System.NullReferenceException
2. Create custom class ViewModel, ex: SampleViewModel
3. Add MVC View using Visual Studio Add View dialog.
    - View name: Sample
    - Template: Create
    - Model: SampleViewModel

4. Add new Sample action on controller and return View() without passing our SampleViewModel object
5. Access the page from browser

Please refer to https://medium.com/@joni2nja/friends-dont-let-friends-swallow-nullreferenceexception-acd949833d70 for detail repro steps with screenshots.

### Expected result
I would expect the model accessor does not swallow the NullReferenceException.

### Actual result
Visual Studio will break on NullReferenceException, swallowing it and returns null.

### Question
I might have missed something, but why model accessor is swallowing NullReferenceException when it sounds like a null check guard should be added to avoid throwing exception?

title: Move to RazorProjectEngine.
body: MvcRazorTemplateEngine isn't used any more. Use RazorProjectEngine.
